collection: Collection of Dr. A. Relph,Sold at Sotheby's June 7, 1936,Lot 38 (sold for 4-5-0)
description: Except for notches chipped out of the edges, in perfect condition: These notches are regular + V shaped + have been made in ancient times, the notch on the inner side of them is of the same dark brown patina as the sword. They have the appearance of having been made deliberately.  Nine rivet holes: three down centre of hilt, three on each shoulder. The midrib of blade continues in the form of a pointed elevation up to the lowest rivet hole in the hilt. Edges of hilt are flanged and two flanges run (from top of hilt, nearly to its face) between the side flanges + the rivet holes. In addition, the two smaller flanges run between these two, for the distance between the uppermost rivet hole + the top of the hilt.
remarks: "B.25 R. Thames" in white ink by ricasso notches.

description: Typology: most of bl. broad v. sl. convex midrib with marked concave e. bevs; bevels terminate in abrupt offsets below shoulders; v. thin but flattened ricassos; tang sides also mainly flat; midridge at tang and shoulders with concave flanking faces; bevelled surfaces around parts of rivet holes; tang end chisel-edged.,Condition: v. sharp edges, v. little dam.; sl. bend in length - tang-skew,Attached Material: blocking one rivet hole - poss. small gravel chip
remarks: Labels/Markings: White ink inscr. "B24", loose hand painted label.,PIF, DF(C), SI; C; Rec. SN Feb.79; Source MV; Old Cards 1

site: Greater London,River Thames,Kingston,"...found on the 9th of January in the present year (1854) by the ballast-heavers employed in deepening the channel of the Thames at Kingston, nearly opposite his house, nine feet under the superstructure of gravel, and resting about two inches in the blue clay. It was discovered within a few yards of the spot where an iron battle-axe had been raised about three years ago, and which Dr. Roots then laid before the society. This site is closely contiguous to that part of the river just above the new bridge at Kingston, where..."(a)
toSearch: Kingston upon Thames, Greater London, UK
width: sh. 61.3; hilt finial 38.2; min blade 31.3; max blade 42.3
patina: Black-brown patina - specled deterioration to dull brown dry sur.; few extremities rubbed gold.
description: Dimensions: L 688mm; Wsh. 61.3; W (hilt finial) 38.2; min W. bl. 31.3; max W bl. 42.3; max B. hilt fg. 10.0; T. bl 9.4,Typology: centre of hilt plate flat, but swelling at base to medial ridge of blade; [steryle] concave-lozenge section; end of hilt finial bevelled off; crest of hilt fg. strong but tending to flatten on shoulders; medial ridge - partly quite angular, partly slightly flattened; rivet round sectioned,Manufacture: ricasso v. [narrow] flattened - [pro...g] sl. indented outline; v. fine clean grooves - poss. cast variably diffuse e. bev. close to e. - close to tip develops into step moulding; shoulder-rivets with flat inner faces and occ. lips - punched; hilt ones with variable bevels around - poss. cast; stump in centre of hilt finial may be remains of cg. jet - or of tang, if so, re-worked in ant.; crude excesses of metal at dam. sh. - not fully worked?,Condition: Blade edges very good and sharp - very minor nicking only - much prob. recent as gold-flecked - as is v. tip which is just bent over; crack on one sh. anc. - dark brown - bending prob. and. too as no sign of recent interference; surviving rivet "S" bent - pres. dam.,Attached Material: patches of granular-textured and lumpy accretion - mainly in hilt - from context. prob.
remarks: Labels/Markings: yellow ink inscr. "B.25"; loose tag label - Root's original,PIF, DF(C); SI; CI; Rec. SN Feb. 79; Source MV
